description: From Middle English chek, chekke, borrowed from Old French eschek, eschec, eschac, from Medieval Latin scaccus, borrowed from Arabic ÿ¥ŸéÿßŸá‚Äé (≈°ƒÅh, ‚Äúking or check at chess, shah‚Äù), borrowed from Persian ÿ¥ÿßŸá‚Äé (≈°√¢h, ‚Äúking‚Äù), from Middle Persian ê≠¨ê≠´ê≠™ê≠†‚Äé (mlk æ /≈°ƒÅh/)[[Category:|CHECK]], from Old Persian êèã (X≈† /x≈°ƒÅyaŒ∏iya/, ‚Äúking‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *k≈°√°yati (‚Äúhe rules, he has power over‚Äù), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *tek- (‚Äúto gain power over, gain control over‚Äù).

All English senses developed from the chess sense. Compare Saterland Frisian Schak, Schach, Dutch schaak, German Schach, Danish skak, Swedish schack, Icelandic sk√°k, French √©chec, Italian scacco. See chess and shah (‚Äúking of Persia or Iran‚Äù), from the same source.

entries.meaning: An inspection or examination.
examples: I don't know if she will be there, but it's worth a check.

entries.meaning: A control; a limit or stop.
examples: checks and balances
The castle moat should hold the enemy in check.

entries.meaning: (chess) A situation in which the king is directly threatened by an opposing piece. [from 14th c.]
(US) A mark (especially a checkmark: ‚úì) used as an indicator.
examples: Synonyms: (UK) tick, checkmark

entries.meaning: (US) An order to a bank to pay money to a named person or entity.
examples: Synonym: (UK, Canada) cheque
I was not carrying cash, so I wrote a check for the amount.

entries.meaning: (US) A bill, particularly in a restaurant.
examples: Synonyms: bill, (Canada) cheque
I summoned the waiter, paid the check, and hurried to leave.

entries.meaning: (contact sports) A maneuver performed by a player to take another player out of the play.
examples: The hockey player gave a good hard check to obtain the puck.

entries.meaning: A token used instead of cash in gaming machines, or in gambling generally.
examples: [‚Ä¶] the statute prohibits a machine which dispenses checks or tokens for replay [‚Ä¶]

entries.meaning: A lengthwise separation through the growth rings in wood.
A mark, certificate, or token by which errors may be prevented, or a thing or person may be identified.
examples: a check given for baggage
a return check on a railroad

entries.meaning: (falconry) The forsaking by a hawk of its proper game to follow other birds. [from 15th c.]
A small chink or crack.

description: From Middle English chekken, partly from Old French eschequier and partly from the noun (see above).

verbs.description: check (third-person singular simple present checks, present participle checking, simple past and past participle checked)

entries.meaning: To inspect; to examine.
examples: Check the oil in your car once a month.
Check whether this page has a watermark.

entries.meaning: To verify the accuracy of a text or translation, usually making some corrections (proofread) or many (copyedit).

(US, often used with "off") To mark items on a list (with a checkmark or by crossing them out) that have been chosen for keeping or removal or that have been dealt with (for example, completed or verified as correct or satisfactory).
examples: Synonyms: check off, (UK) tick, (UK) tick off, cross off, strike off
Antonym: uncheck
Check the items on the list that interest you.
Check off the items that you've checked (inspected).
Check the correct answer to each question.

entries.meaning: To control, limit, or halt.
examples: Synonyms: curtail, restrain; see also Thesaurus:curb
Check your enthusiasm during a negotiation.

entries.meaning: To verify or compare with a source of information.
examples: Check your data against known values.

entries.meaning: To leave in safekeeping.
examples: Check your hat and coat at the door.

entries.meaning: To leave with a shipping agent for shipping.
examples: Check your bags at the ticket counter before the flight.

entries.meaning: (street basketball) To pass or bounce the ball to an opponent from behind the three-point line and have the opponent pass or bounce it back to start play.
examples: He checked the ball and then proceeded to perform a perfect layup.
That basket doesn't count‚Äîyou forgot to check!

entries.meaning: (sports) To disrupt another player with the stick or body to obtain possession of the ball or puck.
examples: Synonyms: tackle, trap, attack
The hockey player checked the defenceman to obtain the puck.

entries.meaning: (poker) To announce that one is remaining in a hand without betting.
examples: Tom didn't think he could win, so he checked.

entries.meaning: (chess) To make a move which puts an adversary's king in check; to put in check.
To chide, rebuke, or reprove.
(nautical) To slack or ease off, as a brace which is too stiffly extended.
To crack or gape open, as wood in drying; or to crack in small checks, as varnish, paint, etc.
To make checks or chinks in; to cause to crack.
examples: The sun checks timber.

entries.meaning: To make a stop; to pause; with at.
examples: The mind, once jaded by an attempt above its power, either is disabled for the future, or else checks at any vigorous undertaking ever after.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To clash or interfere.
To act as a curb or restraint.
examples: It [his presence] checks too strong upon me.

entries.meaning: (falconry) To turn, when in pursuit of proper game, and fly after other birds.

description: By shortening from chequer, from Old French eschequier (‚Äúchessboard‚Äù), from Medieval Latin scaccarium, ultimately from the same Persian root as above.

entries.meaning: (heraldry) Divided into small squares (chequers) by transverse vertical and horizontal lines.
examples: Synonym: chequy

entries.meaning: (textiles, usually pluralized) A pattern made up of a grid of squares of alternating colors; a checkered pattern.
examples: The tablecloth had red and white checks.

entries.meaning: Any fabric woven with such a pattern.

verbs.description: check (third-person singular simple present checks, present participle checking, simple past and past participle checked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To mark with a check pattern.
